body:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship. 

What is Ruqqus going to do about that?  Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?
body_html:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship.

What is Ruqqus going to do about that? Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?
title: Ruqqus' stance on automoderator bots

body:
Sometimes? *Sometimes?* They fucking use it to shadowban users left, right and center and censor whatever topics they feel like censoring that day.

Not being able to delete comments/posts on Ruqqus bots are much less of a problem here, hope it stays that way.

author.bio:
Ruqqus cofounder and lead backend developer.

https://github.com/captainmeta4
author.bio_html:
Ruqqus cofounder and lead backend developer.

https://github.com/captainmeta4

body:
Automoderator serves a legitimate useful purpose in automatically preventing known malicious content from staying up. For example, game phishing sites that trick users into entering their login info in order to get into the account and wipe it of gold/items.

The exact sites will inevitably vary from community to community, based on the nature of the community and what types of malicious content target it. So we do eventually want to have a feature for guildmasters to have a guild blacklist, but any such feature would operate *before* the post is created and saved, and warn the user that "you aren't allowed to post that here, please share something else." That way it's 1) effective, 2) transparent about what's not allowed, and 3) leaves no room for automatic silent kicks.
body_html:
Automoderator serves a legitimate useful purpose in automatically preventing known malicious content from staying up. For example, game phishing sites that trick users into entering their login info in order to get into the account and wipe it of gold/items.

The exact sites will inevitably vary from community to community, based on the nature of the community and what types of malicious content target it. So we do eventually want to have a feature for guildmasters to have a guild blacklist, but any such feature would operate before the post is created and saved, and warn the user that "you aren't allowed to post that here, please share something else." That way it's 1) effective, 2) transparent about what's not allowed, and 3) leaves no room for automatic silent kicks.

body:
I don't see a purpose for it here. I used an automod bot on my subreddit, but I had to because allowing certain things would have gotten the sub shut down, because Reddit.

The biggest problem with an automod bot is that I had to specifically set it up to notify the user that their post was removed. If I was an evil power-mod I could have used it to shadow-remove posts. Basically I could have used auto-mod to shadow ban users on my sub.
body_html:
I don't see a purpose for it here. I used an automod bot on my subreddit, but I had to because allowing certain things would have gotten the sub shut down, because Reddit.

The biggest problem with an automod bot is that I had to specifically set it up to notify the user that their post was removed. If I was an evil power-mod I could have used it to shadow-remove posts. Basically I could have used auto-mod to shadow ban users on my sub.

body:
I only want AutoModerator so posts on +Guilds are consistent. At the moment, I am manually removing posts that don't fit the posting requirements of:

1. Have the guild name
2. Have a short description

With AutoModerator, I would be able to automatically check if the post title starts with a `+` and if the post title length is more than 10 characters.
body_html:
I only want AutoModerator so posts on +Guilds are consistent. At the moment, I am manually removing posts that don't fit the posting requirements of:

  1. Have the guild name
  2. Have a short description

With AutoModerator, I would be able to automatically check if the post title starts with a + and if the post title length is more than 10 characters.

body:
/r/redpandas has huge stickied wall of text on every single post that goes into great detail about how they are endangered and what you can do to help. The exact same information is available on the subreddit sticky post, which likewise is only going to be read by people who would actually donate in the first place.

It's completely useless.

body: This sounds a lot better than what Reddit has. The subreddit I mod gets a lot of spam/doxxing posts and our automod is set to remove those (for example if someone posts a phone number with instructions to harass the owner of that number). I haven't had that problem here, but considering its only a matter of time before people try to use AHS methods to get us banned that would be super useful.
body_html: This sounds a lot better than what Reddit has. The subreddit I mod gets a lot of spam/doxxing posts and our automod is set to remove those (for example if someone posts a phone number with instructions to harass the owner of that number). I haven't had that problem here, but considering its only a matter of time before people try to use AHS methods to get us banned that would be super useful.

guild.name: Ruqqus

parent.body:
Automoderator serves a legitimate useful purpose in automatically preventing known malicious content from staying up. For example, game phishing sites that trick users into entering their login info in order to get into the account and wipe it of gold/items.

The exact sites will inevitably vary from community to community, based on the nature of the community and what types of malicious content target it. So we do eventually want to have a feature for guildmasters to have a guild blacklist, but any such feature would operate *before* the post is created and saved, and warn the user that "you aren't allowed to post that here, please share something else." That way it's 1) effective, 2) transparent about what's not allowed, and 3) leaves no room for automatic silent kicks.
parent.body_html:
Automoderator serves a legitimate useful purpose in automatically preventing known malicious content from staying up. For example, game phishing sites that trick users into entering their login info in order to get into the account and wipe it of gold/items.

The exact sites will inevitably vary from community to community, based on the nature of the community and what types of malicious content target it. So we do eventually want to have a feature for guildmasters to have a guild blacklist, but any such feature would operate before the post is created and saved, and warn the user that "you aren't allowed to post that here, please share something else." That way it's 1) effective, 2) transparent about what's not allowed, and 3) leaves no room for automatic silent kicks.

post.body:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship. 

What is Ruqqus going to do about that?  Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?
post.body_html:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship.

What is Ruqqus going to do about that? Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?
post.title: Ruqqus' stance on automoderator bots

body: I think Ruqqus will be fine since you can't delete posts like on Reddit.
body_html: I think Ruqqus will be fine since you can't delete posts like on Reddit.

post.body:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship. 

What is Ruqqus going to do about that?  Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?
post.body_html:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship.

What is Ruqqus going to do about that? Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?

body:
I think that would be a great idea. My only concern is that it could *theoretically* be open for abuse by bots/spammers. If a spambot or a spammer detects that a post can't be uploaded because of tripping a blacklisted keyword, that would signal to the spambot/spammer to change the wording a little or even replace some characters with lookalikes from other alphabets/scripts/symbols. Rate limiting post attempts might mitigate it to some extent, but won't work against actors with access to various user accounts or IP addresses.
Giving guildmasters the ability to blacklist posts/comments from users less than a certain account age or with a certain minimum age might be solution to that.
body_html: I think that would be a great idea. My only concern is that it could theoretically be open for abuse by bots/spammers. If a spambot or a spammer detects that a post can't be uploaded because of tripping a blacklisted keyword, that would signal to the spambot/spammer to change the wording a little or even replace some characters with lookalikes from other alphabets/scripts/symbols. Rate limiting post attempts might mitigate it to some extent, but won't work against actors with access to various user accounts or IP addresses. Giving guildmasters the ability to blacklist posts/comments from users less than a certain account age or with a certain minimum age might be solution to that.
